headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Kyle Martino is Interviewed about Wrexham's Promotion; Voters Don't Want Biden or Trump. Aired 8:30-9a ET

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: This is the moment that Wrexham, a soccer team that has played in England's fifth tier for 15 years finally got promoted out of the national league. The crowd at the old racehorse ground rushing the field as team owners Ryan Reynold and Rob McElhenney celebrated with a huge, long embrace. Very happy. A few -

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Do you know who shot that video?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Who?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Paul Rudd.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I love that. The two actors brought the club -- bought the club in 2021, documented their story in the FX documentary series "Welcome to Wrexham." The team's popularity in the United States has skyrocketed. ESPN 2 even televising some of its games. And this summer, Wrexham is coming to America to face two of the biggest clubs in the sport, Manchester United and Chelsea.With us now, TNT and HBO Max soccer analyst and former MLS and U.S. men's national team midfielder, Kyle Martino. Good morning.

utterances.speaker: KYLE MARTINO, SOCCER ANALYST, TNT AND HBO MAX
utterances.sentences: Paul Rudd filmed that after - after 12 pints, too. What a day they had.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: His camera work was really good.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It was very steady.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Very steady.

utterances.speaker: MARTINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Is this a "Ted Lasso" moment for these guys? Like it's kind of -- to get here is crazy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Love it. What about Paul Mullin, 47 goals this season?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: So good.

utterances.speaker: MARTINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's the other thing. There's a player named James Vardy. The last time we had this conversation is when Leicester went -- you'll remember that story years ago, where they went and won the Premiere League. That was a team that went through the same sort of scenario of climbing up through the ranks. And when you think of it as an American sports fan, you know, we kind of celebrate mediocrity and, like, you - you're the worst team in the league? Well, here's the first draft pick. And so what's wild about these stories is, some of these players that have side jobs, you know, they're kind of semi- professionals. And Jamie Vardy was a player on that team for Leicester that ended up playing for England and becoming a Premiere League winner. So that's the cool part is these players that are no name players become household names by winning and going up.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: OK, but can we talk about the promotion relegation thing a little more because there is a clip on the show that explains it, which I think is very helpful for people like me.

utterances.speaker: MARTINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, we would need a half an hour to explain it but we'll try to do it in 30 seconds.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, but like I - like I traffic (ph) in like college football. We're like, what is happening here. But I do want to play this to just explain how this works and how different it is.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Imagine, if you will, the NEW YORK YANKEES lose 150 games in a season, they finish dead last, and they have to drop down a league and the following year play against the likes of the Toledo Mudhens and the Sacramento River Cats. And if they keep losing enough, and they keep dropping leagues, then eventually they end up playing beer league softball in Ithaca.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And then I called Humphrey (ph) and I was like, you had a club that had an infrastructure that could at least support an evening of the balance sheet. Can't you theoretically take a team that's in the lowest league and bring them to the top? He said, yes.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: So, what's next for them?

utterances.speaker: MARTINO
utterances.sentences: I mean staying up, right? So, that's the other thing is this - this moment of elation, you know, when you go up, TV rights are bigger, so you get a little bit more money, but you've got to be careful to spend that money wisely. So, the hardest thing to do when you climb the table and you get up to the next division is, of course, you are the biggest in your pond, now you're in a bigger pond and there's faster fish. So, they're in a tougher division. So, staying in that league is everything. I think that's the - that's the thing that everyone worries about is you get really excited, you go up, and then immediately you finish bottom of that table and you drop back down.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Did they spend a lot of money and are they making a lot of money now or are they getting their investment back?

utterances.speaker: MARTINO
utterances.sentences: Well, yes, that's a good question. I think this story, if you tried to do the calculus on how they succeeded, they're not the only famous people that went over and bought a lower division team. I mean this has been going on for a long time. I was a part of the ownership with Steve Nash and Stu Holden and Robert Sarver and we bought Mallorca and had back to back promotions and they're in LaLiga now, but 95 percent of the efforts to do what they're doing fail. This is a really hard thing to do. So, the thing they have is storytelling, right?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MARTINO
utterances.sentences: Now we all know it. Now they -- we all have our phones out. I'm here this morning. You know, five years ago we wouldn't be sitting here telling a story like this. So, you're right, "Ted Lasso," the growth of the game in this country, our women World Cup team being one of the best in the country, this summer hopefully going again to win a World Cup.So, 2026 is going to be the World Cup in the United States. Stories like this, I think, are going to make people, you know, speculate. Can we go over and buy a team? Can we do this? Because the top division teams, you know, the Fenway Sports Group that owned Boston Red Sox -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MARTINO
utterances.sentences: And the Glazers who own obviously Manchester United. Some of the biggest European clubs in the world are owned by Americans.I love that some of these speculative Americans are going, listen, we can tell a big story. The better story is on the way up, not staying there. HARLOW: That's right.

utterances.speaker: MARTINO
utterances.sentences: So, this is going to be fascinating to follow.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Staying there is season two. Getting there is season one.

utterances.speaker: MARTINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. And the -

utterances.speaker: MARTINO
utterances.sentences: And winning the Premiere League is 20 years down the road.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Poppy just won a big pot of money this weekend from winning the marathon.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Are you kidding.

utterances.speaker: MARTINO
utterances.sentences: Are you guys buying a team?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So we're going to - I think we should just buy a - cool to buy a team.

utterances.speaker: MARTINO
utterances.sentences: I want in. Is that why you brought me?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: First of all, I came home from a half-marathon with a medal that everyone gets. And my daughter was like, oh, my God, I'm so excited. We went out to brunch. She saw other people with the medal.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: No!

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: She's like, mom, you didn't win? Everyone gets a medal?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Everyone gets a trophy.

utterances.speaker: MARTINO
utterances.sentences: Participation. You're like, well, I finished, all right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's all I need.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Finished is winning.

utterances.speaker: MARTINO
utterances.sentences: There's a lot of people that didn't finish that race.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: If these legs at my age can finish we're in - I'm happy.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Boy.

utterances.speaker: MARTINO
utterances.sentences: I wouldn't even try it.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Kyle, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thanks, Kyle.

utterances.speaker: MARTINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Good to see you. So, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis in Japan this morning on a quoteinternational trade mission and answering questions about a possible White House run. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Governor, polls show you falling behind Trump. Any thoughts on that?GOV. RON DESANTIS (R-FL): I am not - I am not a candidate. So, we'll see if - if and when that changes. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, happening this morning, President Biden and his team of advisers are finalizing plans to announce his 2024 re-election bid, while former President Trump is already the expected front-runner for Republicans. But in a new poll, voters say they don't want either Biden or Trump to run in 2024.Joining us now, CNN's chief political correspondent and co-anchor of "STATE OF THE UNION," the one and only Dana Bash. Good morning.

utterances.speaker: DANA BASH, CNN CHIEF POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Wow, that was a good intro, Don.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you. I practiced that.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: It was - such feeling. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I was at -- in front of the mirror last night going, the Dana Bash.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Dana Bash.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Dana, good morning.So, what do you - what do you think voters are saying here? Obviously, they do not want 2020 all over again. They're like, let's move on to somebody else. Is that what they're saying?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's very important to note. But there is obviously one person who may be considering trying to challenge Trump for that Republican nomination. That's Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, who is on a trip that is unusual for a sitting governor to take. This is in Japan. He's doing a multi-country tour. But when he was in Japan, Dana, he was asked about falling behind Trump in some of these polls when it comes to who they want to be the Republican candidate. This is how he responded.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Governor, polls show you falling behind Trump. Any thoughts on that?GOV. RON DESANTIS (R-FL): I am not - I am not a candidate. So, we'll see if - if and when that changes. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: What did you make of that, Dana?

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I -- he looked down as he --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's getting a lot of reaction in Trump world, I'll say.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Well, he was looking down as if he was looking for the place where he could hit the button so that the earth could open and he could - he could disappear. That's what I - I took away from his body language there.Look, it's -- we expect him to say that, particularly on the international stage, to be fair, where he's there in his capacity as a sitting governor of Florida. He's not going to say anything political or shouldn't say anything political with regard to his own future there. But the other thing I was thinking about, guys, is, back in May, I believe it was, early June, of 2015. I accompanied then former Florida Governor Jeb Bush on an international trip. He was in Latvia and some of the other former Soviet countries. We actually went to Poland, as well. And it was part of a strategy to show the voters, particularly the Republican primary voters at the time, that he has international chops. That he has foreign policy/national security chops. That's another thing going on here. A big thing going on here with DeSantis and this trip. And we should underline that in a very big way. Whether or not that matters when it comes to what the voters right now are looking for, that is a very big question mark.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I want to talk about your interviews yesterday with both Senator Lindsey Graham and Senator Amy Klobuchar, touched on abortion. But this exchange in particular, and, control room, let's play the shorter Graham sound bite, was interesting, and I think it points to what a number of leaders in the Republican Party are doing to try to describe their view of Democrats on abortion now.Let's play it. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R-SC): I think the Republican Party will be in good standing to oppose late-term abortion, like most of the civilized world.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Just, for the record, Roe went up to viability, but I just want to button this up. The man that you're - the man -

utterances.speaker: GRAHAM
utterances.sentences: No, that's - no, no, quit covering for these guys! No, no, no, you're media, you keep covering for these guys. They introduced legislation that allowed abortion on demand with taxpayer-funded - well, you paying for it, the taxpayer, up to the moment of birth.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GRAHAM
utterances.sentences: That was their position in Washington. That's the law they want to pass. And nobody in your business will talk about it. It's barbaric.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Senator -(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It's not true. And people should watch your full interview with him and you're not covering for anyone.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, boy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But the point about saying abortion on demand up until the term - up until the point of delivery I thought was striking, especially what we heard from Senator Tim Scott on that a few weeks ago.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, what Republicans have been doing since Roe was revoked has been saying there's a very important question to ask, not just of us Republicans when it comes to where -- at what point in a pregnancy abortion should be - be allowed at the beginning of the pregnancy, but the question for Democrats, which is, how long through a pregnancy should abortion be allowed. It's a legitimate question. It is a question that I and I know each of the three of you have asked Democrats repeatedly, because this is a policy that has not had to be set for 50 years while Roe was in place.And so as these states are coming up with their individual new laws, the question is, not just, for example, Florida, you cannot have an abortion after six weeks of pregnancy, but the sort of more liberal states, how long is it OK to do that? It is a legitimate question. It is not legitimate to say we are not asking those questions, because we are.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But -- yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But the other thing I should say is that -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: What that - what that spoke to is how incredible -- and I think you were getting to this in your question, Poppy, how really complicated this issue is.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: On the raw politics for Republicans.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: The whole reason Lindsey Graham proposed a national ban, even though he said he never would during the midterms, is because he understood how complicated it was politically for Republicans, and it still is.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Dana Bash, thank you. Always a pleasure. The Dana Bash, the one and only.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Good to see you guys.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Make sure to watch the one and only Dana Bash, "STATE OF THE UNION," every Sunday, 9

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: New data shows regular phone calls are out and voice notes are in, except if you're me and I call everyone. Harry Enten is here with your morning number. LEMON

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Are you singing, Harry? People think it's like weird when I call them. They're like, why don't you just text me?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, don't call me -(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: HARRY ENTEN, CNN SENIOR DATA REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Hey, Don, I just wanted to let you know that you should send me some dog photos after this segment because if I don't get one I'm going to be really, really sad.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: The voice that you hear there is our CNN senior data reporter Harry Enten, who is here with this morning's number. Not about the number of dog photos you have gotten from Don, but what is the morning number?

utterances.speaker: HARRY ENTEN, CNN SENIOR DATA REPORTER
utterances.sentences: All right, so this morning's -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And he does send those, by the way. Where are the dogs?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Where are they? Where are they? Send a voicemail at least weekly, about one in five on average from data in the U.K. and the USA. And more than that it's on the rise. Take a look here. So, OK, voice memo users rising, up 114 percent since 2019 in the U.K., up 37 percent since 2022 on the dating app Hinge. So, voice memos are becoming significantly more popular.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Why are they becoming more popular, Harry?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: OK. So, how do people talk daily or more in the U.S.? Text messaging is more popular than making a phone call, 68 percent on the text message, 59 percent on the phone call. But let's say you want support, right? You want that human touch. It turns out that people who got support in the last month via phone call, 51 percent, versus text messaging, just 46 percent. So, I think these voice memos kind of create this middle ground, right? It's the phone call's personal touch without the fear of interrupting somebody's day. And I think that's especially big with those under the age of 30, which is close to my age group, but not quite. LEMON

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I like it because, yes, it's like a text where you don't have to type it all out, but also like you're not on the phone with them. There's no obligation. You just get off and you go.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I still call them all the time.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Kaitlan and I agree on this. When someone calls, I'm like, what's wrong? What do you want? Why are you calling?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Like, don't call me.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, just text me.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Like just saying hi, guys.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Oh, no, no, no, don't ever do that to me. You'll freak me out. No, no, no. Text.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Or the people who Facetime out of the blue. I'm like, I'm not answering a Facetime.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, you're like, this is suspicious.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right, Harry Enten, thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Harry.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right, and thank you for joining us this morning. CNN NEWS CENTRAL starts right after this break.
